Award.AwardTitle: 2017 Midwest Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics Conference (MTSM)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant is to provide partial support for the 2017 Midwest Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics (MTSM) Conference to be held on the campus of the University of Notre Dame on June 4-6, 2017. The MTSM Conference has historically provided a forum for researchers working on theoretical and experimental aspects of Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics to come together, present their work and exchange ideas. Most participants will be from chemical engineering and chemistry departments, although students and faculty from physics, materials science, mechanical engineering, and computer science departments have also participated in this conference in the past.

Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics are an important area of research that has a wide spectrum of applications in chemical, biological and natural systems. The MTSM Conference series has a 29-year history and attracts participants from academic institutions, industry and national laboratories. Most attendees are from institutions located in the Midwest region of the US, which has a large concentration of researchers working in the field of Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics. The Conference participants will have the opportunity to attend state-of-the-art invited presentations by leading experts in the field and debate controversial points with their peers. The conference participants supported by this grant will have the opportunity to network with peers from other institutions and exchange ideas about the current status and future directions in research and education in an important area of research: Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics. A distinctive feature of The MTSM Conference is its focus on researchers in the early stages of their academic careers, such as undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs, and junior faculty. Because the meetings are regional and organization costs are kept to a minimum, faculty members are often able to travel with their entire group to the meeting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF-funded project partially supported the 2017 Midwest Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics (MTSM) Conference, hosted June 4-6 2017 on the campus of the University of Notre Dame in Notre Dame, Indiana. The annual conference, which has convened for the past thirty years few interruptions, provides a regional scientific forum for exchanging ideas and fostering collaborations among statistical mechanics and thermodynamics researchers in the Midwestern United States. The conference brings together undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs, young and senior faculty and participants from industrial and national labs. For many of the students (in particular the undergraduates and early graduate students) this is their first experience presenting a poster or talk at a major technical meeting, and they benefit greatly from this experience.

The conference had three primary objectives: (1) to provide a small-scale scientific venue for efficient dissemination of scientific research advances, (2) to facilitate the development of young researchers, particularly undergraduate and graduate students, and (3) to promote the MTSM going forward.

This year’s conference was divided into five sessions (1 poster and 4 oral) and included 23 contributed posters, 41 contributed talks, and five invited talks. The sessions were, in temporal order, (1) a general poster session on the evening beginning the conference, (2) Thermodynamics for Energy Applications, (3) Polymers and Soft Materials, (4) Biological and Bio-Inspired Thermodynamics, and (5) Adsorption, Phase Equilibria, and General Thermodynamics. Invited talks included Christopher Wilmer kicking off session (1) with (2018 MTSM Host, University of Pittsburgh) who spoke on Exploring the phase-space of physisorption of gases in LJ-sphere systems, Daniela Kohen (Carleton College) who presented in session (2) on Molecular Insight on the Behavior of Carbon Dioxide within Zeolites, Charles Sing (2019 MTSM Host-Designate, University of Illinois) who presented in session (3) on Monomer Sequence to Self-Assembly in Charged Polymers, and Andrew Ferguson (University of Illinois) who presented in session (4) on Statistical Learning of Viral Fitness Landscapes. Additionally, a keynote talk by Professor Juan de Pablo (1996 MTSM Host, University of Chicago) was presented at the conference dinner between sessions (3) and (4) on Directed Assembly of Biological Macromolecules, interspersed with some observations from his extensive experience in research.
